coatOfArms.name: Halifax UK
coatOfArms.description: The coat of arms features a golden lion rampant symbolizing courage and strength, flanked by golden wheat sheaves representing agriculture and fertility. The blue and silver colors represent loyalty and peace respectively.

coatOfArms.name: Halifax,UK
coatOfArms.description: The coat of arms features a golden lion rampant symbolizing courage and strength, flanked by golden wheat sheaves representing agriculture and fertility. The blue and silver colors represent loyalty and peace respectively.

coatOfArms.name: Prague
coatOfArms.description: The coat of arms displays a silver castle on a red shield, symbolizing the city’s fortitude and history. The golden crowned lion, the symbol of Bohemia, acts as a supporter, emphasizing royal heritage.

coatOfArms.name: New York City

motto.english: Seal of the City of New York

coatOfArms.description: The coat of arms of New York City features a shield supported by a sailor and a Native American, symbolizing unity and history. An eagle crest represents strength and independence.

coatOfArms.name: New York

motto.english: Seal of the City of New York

coatOfArms.description: The coat of arms of New York City features a shield supported by a sailor and a Native American, symbolizing unity and history. An eagle crest represents strength and independence.

coatOfArms.name: Los Angeles
coatOfArms.description: seat of Los Angeles County, and largest city in California, United States

coatOfArms.name: Alexandria
coatOfArms.description: Alexandria is a major city in Egypt. Lying at the western edge of the Nile River Delta

coatOfArms.name: Bern
coatOfArms.description: city in Switzerland, capital of the canton of Bern and de facto capital of Switzerland

coatOfArms.name: Warsaw
coatOfArms.description: The metropolis stands on the River Vistula in east-central Poland. Its population is officially estimated at 1.86 million residents within a greater metropolitan area of 3.27 million residents, which makes Warsaw the 6th most-populous city in the European Union.

coatOfArms.name: switzerland
coatOfArms.description: The triangular shield shape was frequently used by the federal administration throughout the 20th century, and adopted officially (as emblem of the federal administration, not necessarily as emblem of Switzerland as sovereign entity) in 2017. Precedents for this shield shape go back to designs dated to as early as 1815. The official coat of arms of the Swiss Confederation is a white couped cross in a red heraldic shield, without explicit specification of the shape of the shield, and a variety of shield shapes are in use.

coatOfArms.name: Lower Silesian Voivodeship
coatOfArms.description: The design of the coat of arms had been for the first time used by Henry II the Pious, duke of Wrocław and Greater Poland, and the High Duke of Poland. It was present in his seal, that was used from 1224 to 1240. It depicted an eagle with a crescent put across its wings, with a cross pattée on top of it, in its middle, placed on a shield. Such design was inspired by the seal used by Henry the Bearded, his father. Since then, the black eagle with a white (silver) crescent put across its wings, usually with a white (silver) cross pattée on top of it, placed in the yellow (golden) escutcheon (shield), had become the symbol of the Lower Silesia, including being the symbol of the Piast rulers of the Duchy of Silesia, and many of its successors

coatOfArms.name: Lusatia
coatOfArms.description: The history behind Lusatian coats of arms is deeply intertwined with the region's cultural and political identity. The coat of arms with an ox, which may have been for Lusatia, first appeared in the time of Henry IV of Meissen. It is believed to have been the arms of Henry IV for Lusatia, as it was used in the coat of arms of the Benedictine monastery of Göss, which dates back to the time of King Přemysl Ottokar II the Great. The idea of the ox as the emblem of Lusatia was also put forward around 1520 in George Spalatin's Saxon chronicles.

coatOfArms.name: London
coatOfArms.description: The coat of arms is not just a decorative symbol; it represents the sovereignty and independence of the City of London. It is used in various official capacities, including on documents, buildings, and ceremonial occasions. The arms are also present in stained glass, street furniture, and other public displays throughout the city, reinforcing the identity and heritage of London.

coatOfArms.name: Český Těšín
coatOfArms.description: Český Těšín lies on the west bank of the Olza river, in the heart of the historical region of Cieszyn Silesia. Until the 1920 division of the region between Poland and Czechoslovakia it was just a western suburb of the town of Teschen, which after the division fell to Poland as Cieszyn. The combined population of the Czech and Polish parts of the town is around 57,000 (23,500 in Český Těšín, 33,500 in Cieszyn). The area was originally a small western suburb of the town of Cieszyn, the capital of the Duchy of Cieszyn, which was established in 1290, during the fragmentation of Poland into smaller duchies. It was ruled by the Piast dynasty until 1653, and by the Habsburg dynasty afterwards. Under Austrian rule, it was known under its Germanized name Teschen. It was known for its national and cultural diversity, consisting mostly of German, Polish, Jewish and Czech communities. In 1849, the western part of Teschen was home to only 14.9% of the town's total population: in 1880 24% and in 1910 33.4%. There was also a small but lively Hungarian community in the town, mostly officers and administrative workers.

coatOfArms.name: Cieszyn

motto.english: for 'by love and not by pain'

coatOfArms.description: In 1920 Cieszyn Silesia was divided between the two newly created states of Poland and Czechoslovakia, with the smaller western suburbs of Cieszyn becoming part of Czechoslovakia as a new town called Český Těšín. The larger part of the town joined Poland as Cieszyn. there is also a statue build in Pałac Habsburgów that is poiting at czech part of cieszyn/Těšín

coatOfArms.name: Ostrava
coatOfArms.description: The city's coat of arms features a blue shield with a rearing silver horse standing on a green lawn. The horse wears a golden saddle and a red coverlet. At the top right of the shield there is a golden rose with green leaves and a red core. The horse in the coat-of-arms wears no bridle. The oldest known depiction of this coat-of-arms is on a seal dating from 1426. The first coloured version dates from 1728. The horse is often interpreted as a symbol of Ostrava's position on a major trade route, or as a figure taken from the coat-of-arms of Ostrava's first vogt (reeve), while the golden rose probably comes from the family coat-of-arms of the bishop of Olomouc Stanislav I Thurzo. This explanation is supported by most modern literature

coatOfArms.name: Wroclaw
coatOfArms.description: The coat of arms has undergone several changes throughout history. The first version was created in 1292, featuring only the head of St. John the Baptist. After Wrocław became part of the Kingdom of Bohemia, the Bohemian lion was added. The current design was restored in 1990 after the fall of communism in Poland, reflecting the city's rich history and cultural identity.

usage.name: Afghanistan

motto.native: لَا إِلٰهَ إِلَّا الله مُحَمَّدٌ رَسُولُ الله
motto.english: There is no god but Allah, and Muhammad is the messenger of Allah

usage.description: The national emblem features a mosque with a pulpit and a mihrab, surrounded by sheaves of wheat.

usage.name: Albania
usage.description: A red shield featuring a black double-headed eagle, topped with the golden helmet of Skanderbeg.

usage.name: Algeria
usage.description: The emblem shows the Hand of Fatima under a star and crescent, with symbols of agriculture and industry.

usage.name: Andorra
usage.description: Combines the arms of the Bishop of Urgell and the Count of Foix.

usage.name: Angola
usage.description: Reflects the socialist history with a machete and hoe crossing, and a rising sun.

usage.name: Argentina
usage.description: An oval shield divided into light blue and white with hands holding a pike topped with a liberty cap.

usage.name: Kosovo
usage.description: Partially recognized state. Features the silhouette of the country and stars representing its ethnic groups.
